markdownRemark.html:
Around a week ago, I found that one of my clients' websites had been hacked by someone. Since restoring a website was a rare opportunity to me, I wrote this short article.

Problem

  • A Wordpress website had been hacked
  • Once a user visited the website, they were redirected to website(s) the hacker chose.
  • I could not access wp-admin since I was redirected to another website right away.

Derived Problems

  • Theoretically, the website was supposed to be removed from search engines (in case of the website, since the website is for Korean users, I expected it on Naver which is the biggest search engine in South Korea)

    • Since I found the problem within a few days after the incident, it did not happen.

Cause

  • The address js.digestcolect.com was used for redirection

    • In header, js.digestcolect.com was used for pingback

    • Near the end of body, I found that several JavaScript were added by the attacker.

      • Once someone visits the website, the script had been executed.
      • To achive the redirection, the attacker had used Sydney theme and Elementor plugin.
      • Found that the theme and plugin had not been updated for a while (probably less than a month)

Solution - General

  • Visited its hosting website right away

    • To check whether somebody tried to sign in my hosting account
    • It was not affected, so I changed its password first

  • Changed passwords for 1) database and 2) SSH

    • Once you changed the database password, check the website again. If something was changed, it was likely that there was a cause in the database as well.

  • Did Curl on Terminal to see what caused such redirection.

    • Useful to know which part caused redirection.

Solution - Database

  • Accessed the database and checked all tables

    • wp_options are commonly used to achieve redirection.
    • Checked wp_statistics_visitor to know 1) when and 2) how the attack was happened.

Solution - Wordpress

  • Checked the theme and plugin's files whether the attacker also changed the files.

    • Both Sydney theme and Elementor plugin had been manipulated.
    • The result of doing Curl was helpful. (because I found which parts caused the redirection problem)
